description.narrative: The project aims at developing climate resilience of farming and pastoral communities in the drought prone parts of Uzbekistan, specifically Karakalpakstan

participating-org.narrative: Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development

activity-description.narrative: Implementation of a) Institutional and technical capacity building activities for drought management and early warning; b) Climate resilient farming practices on subsistence dekhkan farms; c) Landscape level adaptation measures for soil conservation and moisture retention improved climate resilience

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development
Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development
Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development
Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1 # of automated meteo stations and monitoring equipment for field data collection and transmission 1.2 Coverage of hydro-meteorological observation network on km2 1.3 Lead time (weeks) for drought early warning 1.4.1 # of Field School/Extension services delivering training in adaptation practices to farmers and pastoralists 1.4.2 % Dekhkan farmers (including % of female Dekhkan farmers) receiving extension services to introduce farm-based climate risk management measures 2.1 # of dekhkan farmers (% of women) adopted conservation agriculture practices (e.g. low till, mixed cropping, fodder production, and residue crop soil) 2.2 # of dekhkan farmers (% of women) adopted water saving irrigation practices (e.g. land levelling, furrow and drip irrigation systems) 2.3 # of Dekhans established horticulture greenhouses and # of female lead ones 2.4 # of legal acts and regulations enacted to support well tested farm-based adaptation measures 3.1 # of ha with saksaul and tamarix plantations to deliver sand stabilization and soil desalinization function 3.2 # of Dekhkan farmer and pastoral community members (% of women) involved in landscape level adaptation measures (e.g. saksaul and tamarix planting) through local employment programme 3.3 # of cooperatives established at Khokimiyat and Makhalla levels for community management of sand stabilizing plantations 4.1 # of documented good practices (bulletins) of agronomic and water saving measures 4.2 # of lessons learned bulletins disseminated through printed and web-based media 4.3 # of farm and pasture land demonstration meetings covered by media and attended by national and local authorities 5.1 Monitoring and Evaluation system is in place 5.2 Project outputs and outcomes evaluated at mid and final points of project implementation cycle, and lessons learned codified

comment.narrative: 1.1 Density of meteorological and hydrological stations is insufficient to provide adequate coverage for drought monitoring 1.2 Lack of data (insufficient coverage) to adequately monitor climate and water supply status 1.3 Warning systems are not linked with water user and farmer groups; and drought early warning is not effectively and timely delivered 1.4 No extension services for climate change adaptation by farmers in place 2.1 Low awareness of dekhkan farmers on adaptation solutions to optimize agricultural production and minimize the adverse impacts of droughts both in short and long term 2.2 Low awareness of dekhkan farmers on water saving irrigation practices 2.3 Limited use of horticulture greenhouses as drought mitigation solutions 2.4 Insufficient legal and regulatory framework to support well-tested farm-based adaptation measures 3.1 Insufficient coverage of landscape level adaptation measures (plantations) for sand stabilization and moisture retention 3.2 Low involvement of dekhkan farmers and pastoral community in landscape level adaptation measures 3.3 Lack of institutional mechanisms for community management of sand stabilizing plantations 4.1 Some water saving irrigation and agronomic methods were sporadically demonstrated but farmers continue inefficient and unsustainable practices that increase their vulnerability to drought and climate change risks 4.2 Lessons learned are not being captured for broader sharing to address an aggravation of the food security situation during the droughts and as a result of climate change 4.3 Outreach mechanism, transmission of knowledge is limited in scope (within the scientific community), not well tailored or systematic 5.1 No Monitoring and Evaluation system 5.2 No evaluation of project output and outcomes

Target 1 1.1 2 Doppler water meters and 9 automated meteo stations installed and they are provided coverage of 15000 km2 with data for hydrometeorological and drought monitoring. 1.2 At least 15,000 km2 of the Karakalpakstan region covered by automated hydro-meteorological observation network. 1.3 8 months lead time drought early warning developed and are available for end-users. 1.4.1 3 Extension Services established and delivered trainings for subsistence dekhan farmers with provision of knowledge products. 1.4.2 At least 25% (at least 20% of them are female) of Dekhkan farmers and pastoralists of Karakalpakstan region served by science-based extension.
Target 2 2.1 At least 20,000 Dekhkan farmers adopted climate resilient conservation agriculture practices (low till, mixed cropping, fodder production, and residue crop soil). 2.2 At least 20,000 Dekhan farmers adopted water saving irrigation practices (e.g. land levelling, furrow, drip irrigation systems) at 40,000 ha dekhkan farms to improve farm-level drainage and minimize salinization). 2.3 20% (3,200 of households (3 women-led) or approx. 16,000 people) of targeted Dekhan farmers have established horticulture greenhouses on 8,000 ha of farms to minimize impacts of droughts on farm production. 2.4 At least 2 laws/regulations on agricultural practices and water management amended and integrated into regulations to support adoption of conservation agriculture and water saving techniques and technologies on the farms.
Target 3 3.1 Over 30,000 ha of arid land of Karakalpakstan covered with saksaul and tamarix plantations to deliver sand stabilization and soil desalinization function. 3.2 N/A 3.3 At least 10 community organizations (at least 10 female groups and village organizations) at khokimiyat and makhalla level have clear mandates, institutional capacities and skills and manage saksaul and tamarix plantations.
Target 4 4.1 2 bulletin included information about results of inventory of all tested water saving measures and successful practices mapped out. 4.2 At least 10 lessons learned for climate resilient agricultural and pastoral production systems in arid lands developed and included into associated publications and web-based disseminated. 4.3 At least 4 farm and pasture land demonstration meetings with participation of national, local authorities, media and communities, and associated printing and publications produced and disseminated.
Target 5 5.1 N/A 5.2 N/A

Target 1 1.1 2 Doppler water meters installed and are successfully being used in Tuyamuyn and Kipchak water gauge stations. 4 of 10 installed automated meteorological stations (AMS) are not operational. One was dismounted due to displacement from territory of newly built-up airport in Muynak but has not been reinstalled at new place yet. 3 stations are not operational due 3 data loggers got faulty. Recalled equipment was sent to manufacturer for inspection , repairment or replacement. Data base and data base management software to store and grant an access to all data collected from AMS were developed. An access to the whole amount of data collected from two automated agro-meteorological stations (Kegeily and Knalikul districts ) and stored at the vendors remote server is ensured with software specifically developed for this service. As of today, the operational part of AMS network covers 32,000 km2 with data for hydrometeorological monitoring. Due date to get AMS network fully operational is end of May, 2021.
1.2 32,000 km2 of the region are covered with the observation network. Areal coverage is extended with help of two automated agrometeorological stations installed in Kegeily and Kanlikol districts.
1.3 The approach and operational algorithm to produce 8 months lead time drought warnings based on the High Order Spectrum analysis and Singular Spectrum Analysis developed. These are being integrated into the existing Drought Early Warning System (DEWS) modules to ensure the early warning availability for end-users. The existing DEWS adapted to Amudarya river downstream is extended with the additional hydrological objects and is able to issue the 6 months lead time warnings on water resources availability and/or drought warnings with validity of 70-100% for each hydrological object included into system. Due date to get DEWS operational for issuing early warnings to the end-users is end of June 2021.
1.4.1 7,207 (28% female) dekhkans, farmers, pastoralists and representatives of rural local communities have been served by the 3 Extension Services Centers established under Nukus Branch of Tashkent State Rural University in Nukus; under the Agricultural College in Kegeily district, and in LLC Agrotech Service in Kanlikul district with consultations on innovative and climate resilient agro conservation and water saving practices through telecommuting mode due to COVID-19 lockdown restrictions, which were focused on provided the only telecommuting-based consultations due to the COVID19 lockdown restrictions, including on: 1) Water saving practices applicable to water deficient periods (to all 6 project pilot districts during March-May 2020); 2) Sustainable land management approaches (to all 6 project pilot districts during February-August 2020); 3) Land laser leveling applications (to Chimbay, Kegeily, Takhatkupir and Kanlikul pilot districts in spring season of 2020); 4) Zero tillage applications (to Kegeyli, Bozataw, Kanlikul, Chimbay and Takhtakupir pilot districts in March-April 2020); 5) Water saving practices on gravity driven drip irrigation system applicable for local communities (to all 6 project pilot districts in February-August 2020).
1.4.2 7,207 (28% female) , i.e. 35% of the final target which is 22% of the total amount of the dekhkans, farmers, pastoralists and representatives of rural local communitiesin Karakalpakstan served by the 3 Extension Services Centers established under Nukus Branch of Tashkent State Rural University in Nukus; under the Agricultural College in Kegeily district, and in LLC Agrotech Service in Kanlikul district with consultations on innovative and climate resilient agro conservation and water saving practices through telecommuting mode due to COVID-19 lockdown restrictions.
Target 2
2.1 17,642 stakeholders (49% women) adopted and are benefited from use of conservation agriculture practices, including zero tillage (1,123 people, 15% female), mulching (663 people, 10% female), bio-protection of crops and improvement of land fertility (1,815 people, 26% female), crops residue retention at soil (2,710 people, 49% female), fodder production (9,046 people, 49% female), fodder production with help of hydroponic equipment (2286 people, 49% female) in 6 project pilot districts through the technical assistance provided, 6 telecommuting workshops and consultations held by the 3 established Extension Service Centers.
2.2 34,051 (41% female) stakeholders adopted and are benefited from use of water saving irrigation technologies, including land laser leveling (3,000 people, 15% female), irrigated water saving practices and liman irrigation (21,876 people, 49% female) in the 2 project pilot districts (Bozataw and Takhtakupir) as well as benefited from intensive gardening equipped with solar-powered drip irrigation systems (9,175 people, 30% female) with physical (before COVID pandemic and within time period with restrictions lifted), remote or telecommuting (during the restrictions related to COVID pandemic put in place) technical assistance provided by the project included procurement of equipment, conducting field trainings and provision of consultations by the 3 established Extension Service Centers.
2.3 21,819 (24% female) stakeholders are benefited from hot beds established including 7,371 (27% female) directly benefited and 14,448 (23% female) indirectly benefited. 6 women-led hotbeds established at households plots and school yard in Kanlikol pilot district after installation of 23 hotbeds with total area 2,300 m2. Due to COVID19 lockdown restrictions, installation of 91 hot beds in the project pilot districts is postponed until the restrictions lifted.
2.4 2 (two) legal governmental regulatory documents Concept of development of water management sector of the Republic of Uzbekistan for 2020-2030 (Presidential Decree, 19 February 2020 ) and Strategy for the Development of Agriculture of the Republic of Uzbekistan for 2020-2030 (Presidential Decree, 24 October 2019) amended with the formulated recommendations aimed at mainstreaming the climate change adaptation framework into national policy agenda.
Target 3
3.1 39,500 ha of degraded lands reclaimed through afforestation (21,500 ha by the State Forestry Committee (SFC) with project technical support) and with help of liman irrigation (18,000 ha) by pasture cooperates established with project support.
3.2 N/A
3.3 10 pasture cooperatives established (nine in 2018 and one in 2019) in each of project pilot districts joined 47,830 (49% female) pastoralists from rural communities to implement pasture reclamation for achieving increased pasture productivity. 10 women led groups with clear mandates and having relevant skills to manage afforestation framework aimed at supporting the pasture reclamation activities and ensuring equitable distribution of incomes generated by cooperatives are in place. Women-led groups that joined 108 members initiated and supported sowing and planting works in 5 desert plants nurseries with area of 50 ha through seeds collection, in which involved 189 women and resulted in 2,100 kg of seeds gathered for desert plants nurseries to grow seedlings and saplings.
Target 4
4.1 Two bulletins (publications): one with consolidated information about the 11 lessons learned from the climate-smart agriculture (CSA) development in the northern part of Karakalpakstan and another with science-based applied agrotechnical practices recommended to use for the situations with different water availability (medium, low and extremely low) published and disseminated. Additionally, the brochure on social, economic and environmental benefits of climate resilient agriculture with use of hydroponic technique for green fodder production, a workable best practice, published and disseminated among the project stakeholders and beneficiaries.
4.2 11 lessons learned from the climate-smart agriculture (CSA) development in the northern part of Karakalpakstan grouped into the three following categories: 1) sustainably increased agricultural productivity and incomes; 2) adaptation and increased resilience to climate change impacts; and 3) reduction or avoiding greenhouse gas emissions based on approaches and best practices on for successful CSA implementation disseminated by FAO were published in bulletins and posted in project website for wider dissemination.
4.3 Due to COVID19 lockdown restrictions, the field demonstration meetings and workshops to be focused on climate change adaptation and on increasing climate change resilience were not conducted. However, the targets expected to be achieved through conducting meetings and workshops indicated above are achieved with help of local project moderators and telecommuting meetings. At least 18 relevant telecommuting meetings were held during the reporting period.
Target 5 5.1 N/A 5.2 N/A

Target 1 1.1 2 Doppler water meters and 9 automated meteo stations installed (the 10th which was installed in Muynak district was dismounted as its location coincides with new airport infrastructure construction, and therefore it will be moved into a new location). Data that comes from these stations are widely available through internet-based platform (Field Climate/NG by Meteos). 30,450 km2 of spatial coverage is ensured by the automated meteorological observation ensured; 1.2 30,450 km2 of spatial coverage ensured by the automated meteorological observation network; 1.3 Drought Early Warning System (DEWS) adapted to Amudarya river downstream provides 6 months lead time warnings on water resources deficiency and/or drought with warnings with validity of 70-100%. DEWS is being equipped with additional tools to increase the early warning lead time to 8 months; 1.4.1 3 Extension Services Centers established under Nukus Branch of Tashkent State Rural University in Nukus; Agricultural College in Kegeily district and LLC Agrotech Service in Kanlikul district along with 10 Field Schools delivered trainings on: 1) Water saving practices applicable to water deficient periods (conducted in all 5 project pilot districts in May 2019); 2) Sustainable land management approaches (conducted in all 5 project pilot districts in September-November 2019); 3) Land laser leveling applications (conducted in all 5 project pilot districts in spring season of 2019; 4) Zero tillage applications (conducted in Kegeyli, Kanlikul, Chimbay and Takhtakupir pilot districts in February-April 2019); 5) Water saving practices on gravity driven drip irrigation system applicable for local communities (conducted in all 5 project pilot districts in May-September 2019). Overall, since the inception 10,468 (20% females) farmers, householders and pastoralists trained; 1.4.2 5,904 (11% of 51,208 as the total number of Dekhkan farmers and pastoralists in 5 project pilot districts in Karakalpakstan, of which 26.4 % are women) representatives of local communities are trained or consulted on available innovative agro-conservation and water saving practices by the established 3 Extension Services Centers.
Target 2 2.1 4,870 stakeholders (30% of women) adopted and are benefitted from use of zero tillage (310 people, 15% of women), mulching (183 people, 10% of women), bio-protection of crops and improvement of land fertility (501 people, 26% of women), crops residue retention at soil (748 people, 49% of women), fodder production (2,497 people, 49% of women), fodder production with use of hydroponic equipment (631 people, 49% women) in 5 project pilot districts through technical assistance provided by 10 Field Schools, 62 hands-on workshops and consultations provided by the established 3 Extension; 2.2 5193 of dekhans and farmers (43% of women) adopted and are benefited from water saving irrigation practices. Use of land laser leveling (102 people, 12% of women) at 1,246 ha (296 ha in Kegeli district, 280 ha in Takhatakupir district, 310 ha in Chimbay district, and 360 in Kanlykul district), which saved up to 2,024 mln m3 of water that was sufficient for irrigation of 1,156 household plots (i.e. 6,300 people (50% women) got irrigation water); 12,000 of degraded pasture lands rehabilitated through liman irrigation approach (4,282 people, 40% of women) in Chimbay and Kegeyli pilot districts that resulted in 2 times increased productivity of pastures for 10,513 heads of big cattle and 18,391 heads of small cattle belonging to 2,760 rural households (21,089 people, 49% women). 2,331 people (39% women) are skilled to use drip irrigation, and 630 people (50% women) use drip irrigation systems at their household plots (43 in Muinak district, 213 in Kanlikul district, 137 in Kegeyli district; 155 in Chimbay district, and 82 in Takhtakupir district) 7 intensive gardens on a total area of 14 hectares were established and equipped with a drip irrigation system. 35 people (49% of women) are direct beneficiaries, and 1,500 people (50% of women) are indirect beneficiaries as consumers; 2.3 1,154 Dekhans (40% of women) established horticulture greenhouses and hotbeds. 3 women-led hotbeds established by households at their plos and at school plots in Kanlikul, Chimbay and Takhtakupir districts. 595 households (30% women) established hotbeds by their own initiatives in 2019 as being inspired by the project experience. In addition, another 534 households (50% of women) use greenhouses (2,670 their family members (46% women are benefited from their greenhouse products). 7 intensive gardens established at 14 ha and are watered with use of drip irrigation systems (35 persons (49% women) are direct beneficiaries, while 1,500 (50% women) are indirect beneficiaries from the garden products); 2.4 Law on Food Security includes recommendation on promotion of well-tested farm-based adaptation measures tested by the project that can be replicated and up-scaled. 580 representatives of stakeholder, including 140 (24.1% women) are increased their knowledge through training focused on expertise and assistance in developing/improving the regulatory framework to stimulate the widespread use of well-tested agricultural measures of climate change adaptation.
Target 3 3.1 13,600 ha (of 3,000 ha committed as per MOU signed with the State Committee for Forestry in 2018) afforested by the State Committee for Forestry in 2019; 3.2 9 cooperatives established at 2018 and 1 cooperative is established in 2019 that all joined 47,830 (49% women) pastoralists from rural communities to implement pasture reclamation activities aimed at increasing pasture productivity, and to establish 15,307 ha of new pasture lands as a source for cattle fodder. 3.3 10 communities with leadership based on cooperative management established in all 5 project pilot districts that are joined 47,830 (49%women) pastoralists to implement pasture reclamation activities to increase pasture productivity, and to establish 15,507 ha of new pasture lands as a source of cattle fodder. 10 female groups led by women are in place and contribute to pasture reclamation works with ensuring equality of the wealth distribution produced by the cooperatives.
Target 4 4.1 A bulletin included information about results of inventory of all tested agronomic measures and successful practices, and 11 lessons learned from the climate-smart agriculture (CSA) development in the northern part of Karakalpakstan published and disseminated. Lessons are grouped into the three categories: 1) sustainably increased agricultural productivity and incomes; 2) adaptation and resilience increase to climate change impacts; and 3) reduction or avoiding greenhouse gas emissions based on approaches and best practices on for successful CSA implementation disseminated by FAO. 4.2 A bulletin published and disseminated included information about 11 lessons learned from the climate-smart agriculture (CSA) development in the northern part of Karakalpakstan that are grouped into the three categories: 1) sustainably increased agricultural productivity and incomes; 2) adaptation and resilience increase to climate change impacts; and 3) reduction or avoiding greenhouse gas emissions based on approaches and best practices on for successful CSA implementation disseminated by FAO. 4.3 34 demonstration meetings and workshops focused on climate change adaptation and on increasing climate change resilience held with participation of 2,508 people (23% female) represented the target local communities. Information on the events’ outcomes posted at newspapers and web-resources, and broadcasted via national and regional radio and TV.
Target 5 5.2 N/A 5.2 N/A .

Target 1 1.1 1 automated meteo station reinstalled, all faulty sensors are replaced with operable ones and whole automated observational hydrometetrological network (10 AWS) provides coverage of 40 000 km2 with data for hydrometeorological and drought monitoring. 1.2 At least 8,000 km2 of the Karakalpakstan region covered by automated hydro-meteorological observation network. 1.3 Season ahead (8 months) low water and drought warning is practiced. 1.4.1 N/A 1.4.2 At least 15% (at least 20% of them are female) of Dekhkan farmers and pastoralists of Karakalpakstan region served by science-based extension.
Target 2 2.1 At least 1500 Dekhkan farmers adopted climate resilient conservation agriculture practices (low till, mixed cropping, fodder production, and residue crop soil). 2.2 At least 2800 Dekhan farmers adopted water saving irrigation practices (e.g. land levelling, furrow, drip irrigation systems) at 80,000 ha dekhkan farms to improve farm-level drainage and minimize salinization). 2.3 5% (2000 of households (5 women-led) or approx. 10000 people) of targeted Dekhan farmers have established horticulture greenhouses on 1,5 ha of farms to minimize impacts of droughts on farm production. 2.4 N/A
Target 3 3.1 Over 20,000 ha of arid land of Karakalpakstan covered with saksaul and tamarix plantations to deliver sand stabilization and soil desalinization function. 3.2 43,000 people (50% of women) organized in 10 cooperatives based on khokimiyat and makhalla that are involved in sand stabilization plantation activities as employment scheme. 3.3 At least 10 community organizations (at least 10 female groups and village organizations) at khokimiyat and makhalla level have clear mandates, institutional capacities and skills and manage saksaul and tamarix plantations.
Target 4 4.1.2 sets of bulletins included information about results of inventory of all tested agronomic and water saving measures and successful practices mapped out. 4.2 At least 11 of lessons learned covering successful climate resilient agronomic and water saving measures documented in bulletins produced and disseminated. 4.3 At least 5 farmland demonstration meetings covered by the local and national media for adaptation advocacy
Target 5 5.1 N/A 5.2 Final evaluation conducted in the end of project, and its results and lessons learned are available.

Target 1 1.1 Faulty data loggers (3) and sensors (7) replaced with the operational ones and grounding profile was re-installed for all 10 automated weather stations (AWS) and 2 acoustic Doppler Current Profilers that are fully operational, and are an integrated part of meteo and hydro data exchange network of Uzhydromet. All AWS are equipped with either solar panel (with invertors and high capacity accumulators) for power supply to minimize gaps in data transmission flow. Arial coverage with meteorological data is about 200,000 km2 for all meteorological variables for hydrometeorological and drought monitoring.Two automated agro-meteorological stations without coverage with meteorological data by Uzhydromet observational network installed in Kegeily and Kanlykul districts are operational, and their data are widely available through telegram bot developed by the project (@FieldClimate) 1.2 Whole automated weather stations network (10 AWS) is fully operational and its coverage with meteorological data is about 200,000 km2 of Karakalpakstan for all meteorological variables as being based on calculation done with help of relationships coefficient pair correlation (r) vs distance for minimal level of confidence (r=0.7) 1.3 Drought Early Warning System (DEWS) as a mechanism of low water and drought early warning (based on the multiple methods) developed is operated by Uzhydromet. It enables issuing early warnings with the lead time of 8 months and validity 70-100%. Multifunctional informational platform (MIP) enabling the extended stakeholders’ coverage (at least up to 50,000 people) installed in 15 line ministries and agencies. 20 specialists are trained on MIP use. Since the project inception (2014), 115 specialists (20% females) from Uzhydromet and line ministries trained on use of DEWSs products (quantitative and qualitative values in early warnings on water availability). 5,157 (17% female) received Drought Early Warnings on the long-term (6-8 months) water availability assessment for Amudarya river downstream conditions as well as recommendations on actions ought to be undertaken depending on level of water deficiency to mitigate potential risk of crops loss through the informational bulletins or notes 1.4.1 Three Extension Service Centers (ESC) established in 2017-2019, and served 8,089 (27% female) rural households with consulting and trainings 1.4.2 Since the project inception (2014), 21,200 (27% female) Dekhkan farmers, pastoralists and members of rural communities in 6 project pilot districts that is 36% of the total 58,973 of their total number in Karakalpakstan trained in and/or consulted on available innovative agro-conservation and water saving practices by the 3 Extension Services Centers established with the project support. This was achieved through the conducted 148 indoor or field training and Framers Day/Field Day events conducted with the project support and covered 10,476 (23% female) people. In 2020-2021, almost all consultancy and training services were delivered in telecommuting mode due to COVID-19 lockdown restrictions for travels to regions and for offline meetings. This resulted in 36% coverage of trained/consulted people instead of the planned 40%. Target 2 2.1 13,910 (45% female) agrarians adopted the climate resilient conservation agriculture practices in 2021. Since the project inception (2014), the agro-conservation and water saving practices and technologies were implemented at 59,804 ha of lands. 41,194 (43% female) end-users (against 40,000 set as end-project target) adopted agro-conservation practices 2.2 10,875 (40% female) agrarians adopted water saving practices. Since project inception, 59,804 ha were covered by agro-conservation and water saving technologies. 43,750 (39% female) end-users (against 40,000 set as the end-project target) adopted water saving practices resulted in annual water saving of 18 mln m3 2.3 Since project inception, 10,928 households and 5 schools, i.e. 57,875 (47% female) people, represented 29% of the total 58,973 target farmers, dekhan farmers and households in Karakalpakstan (as of September 2021). Achievement of the end-project target of 40% of end-users is lagged due to COVID 19 pandemic impacts and restrictions for practicing indoor cultivation. Advantages of indoor cultivation were demonstrated by the project and triggered dissemination and scaling-up of this best practice. Coverage of indoor cultivation reached 8450 ha in 2021 Target 3 3.1 During the reporting period 54,300 ha afforested by the State Forestry Committee of the Republic of Karkalpakstan with project technical assistance. 9,000 ha of degraded pastures rehabilitated through use of liman irrigation. Vegetation rehabilitated at 63,300 ha of degraded pasturelands. 10.3 mln saksaul seedlings grown in 5 desert plant nurseries established with the project assistance at over 50 ha that transferred to the State Forestry Committee of the Republic of Karkalpakstan and planted on over 10,300 ha in fall-winter season 2021. Pasture cooperatives in 6 pilot districts are engaged in growing and plantings of saksaul seedlings. Since the project inception, 102,800 ha of extremely degraded lands rehabilitated through established saksaul plantations (75 800 ha) and rehabilitated pasturelands (27 000 ha). This resulted in avoided re-salinization of 697,000 ha of lands 3.2 Additional 3 pasture cooperatives established by rural communities in Kanlykul and Kegeily districts without project support but inspired by the benefits of cooperative model implemented within the project. Since the project inception (2014), 10 cooperatives established with the project support in 2018-2019 joined 64,723 (50.3% female) people. Detailed plans on pasture management with pastoralist scheme employment developed for each pasture cooperative with consideration of geo-botanic survey results. Annually, 110,000 people, including seasonal workers, are engaged in afforestation, maintenance of desert plant nurseries, seeds collection, maintenance of micro and macro irrigation network for pasture reclamation 3.3 10 women-led groups (106 women-activists) established under 10 pasture production cooperatives and contributed to pasture reclamation activities and ensured equitable distribution of incomes generated by the cooperatives. Established pasture cooperatives have a clear mandate and legal institutional status to implement afforestation and pasture reclamation activities and capacities built on development and implementation of detailed plan on pasture management as an employment scheme for members of rural communities Target 4 4.1 Two sets of bulletins included consolidated information about all lessons learned from application of climate-smart agriculture (CSA) in the northern part of Karakalpakstan within the project activity, and another one presented the inventory of all science-based agrotechnical practices recommended for application in Karakalpakstan published and posted at the project website 4.2 Since project inception, 4 bulletins produced and published, and included 11 lessons learned from application of climate-smart agriculture (CSA) in the northern part of Karakalpakstan focused on: • sustainably increased agricultural productivity and incomes; • adaptation and increased resilience to climate change impacts through implementation of CSA approaches and best practices promoted by FAO; • introduction of climate-resilient, agro-saving and environment-friendly practices in the northern regions of Karakalpakstan; • introduction of climate-resilient water-saving practices in the northern regions of Karakalpakstan; • review of agro-conservation and water saving practices applied in Northern part of Karakalpakstan 4.3 18 field demonstration and telecommuting based meetings/workshops focused on climate change adaptation and climate resilient agriculture conducted within the periods of COVID19 restriction down that were attended by 1,087 (23% female) people. Since project inception (2014), 148 demonstration meetings and workshops focused on climate change adaptation and climate resilient agriculture conducted in both offline and online mode that were attended by 14,198 (27% female) people from target local communities. Information about their outcomes was posted in local press and internet resources as well as broadcasted via national and regional radio and TV channels Target 5 5.2 Terminal evaluation conducted by a team of independent international and national evaluators. TE outcomes and recommendations posted at https://www.adaptation-fund.org/project/developing-climate-resilience-of-farming-communities-in-the-drought-prone-parts-of-uzbekistan/
